thread.title: Blacktown Council orders MCW tag to pay to play oztag
thread.title_full: Blacktown Council orders MCW tag to pay to play oztag | News Local

author: Marissa Georgopoulos
title: Blacktown Council orders MCW tag to pay to play oztag

organizations.name: mt druitt town rangers football club

text:
Ken Aumua, Osselan Tupai and Ejay Taulii are disappointed that Blacktown Council says they need to pay to play oztag at Poppondetta Park. Picture: Justin Sanson The Standard Blacktown Council orders MCW Tag to pay to play oztag Marissa Georgopoulos, February 7, 2017 6:20pm NRL stars love playing oztag ‘I am tumour-free. I am lucky’ Panthers throw support behind Jordan
Friendly oztag games helping to keep youth off the streets have been put on hold after Blacktown Council told the group to pay up or move on.
‘Mounty County Wolfpack’ organiser Osselan Tupai has been told to stop the free afternoon friendly games, which are not competitive, at Emerton’s Popondetta Park or apply to hire the grounds.
The group, MCW Tag, which can attract up to 100 people and NRL stars such as Tyrone May from the Penrith Panthers, the Canberra Raiders’ Blake Austin and the Eels’ Suaia Matagi, aims to keep kids off the streets and having fun with people their own age.
NRL stars join MCW tag initiative 1:56 Players often get involved in friendly Oztag games held at Popondetta Park, Emerton to help keep youths off the street.
November 16th 2016 3 months ago /video/video.news.com.au/Sport/ NRL stars join MCW tag initiative Games have been called off since late last year for fear of legal action.
The letter, sighted by The Standard , said council had “concerns”, as the “organised tag league” had not approached council for approval, provided public liability insurance proof, nor had it paid any fees.
It also said the group failed to meet requirements for sporting clubs, which included noting its affiliation with a state sporting organisation and providing business plans, and stated police might be called if no arrangements were made with council.
media_camera Some of the Mounty County Wolfpack, including their youngest members, pictured before they were ordered off the field by council. Photo: Justin Sanson
However, Blacktown Council this week reached out to Mr Tupai after The Standard raised the issue.
A spokesman said he was hoping to discuss the best way they can use the council-owned sporting fields.
“The invitation has been sent, and we look forward to having a productive meeting with them,” he said.
“It was upsetting to get that (email),” Mr Tupai said. “This all started with us trying to have some fun and then we noticed young kids were coming in and we took that on board.
“We took them in because parents started saying it kept their kids off the streets and out of trouble.
media_camera NRL players Blake Austin from the Raiders, Suaia Matagi of the Eels and Panther Tyrone May with youngsters (from left) Malakai Talatau, Tarrell Savaiinaea, Prynce Matagi, Jahmar Kahuroa and Sean Pokia. Picture: Justin Sanson
“Everything changed then — the motivation of why we played changed, just because of that.”
It costs $455 to hire one of the council’s fields over a summer season.
Mr Tupai said the group only ever used available fields and the sessions have become so popular NRL players have turned up to support the youngsters.
Penrith Panthers’ Tyrone May and Canberra Raider Blake Austin, who grew up in the area, have often played with the group.
More recently, Panthers young gun Nathan Cleary met with some of them.
media_camera Parramatta Eels signing Suaia Matagi loves mentoring the younger players from the area. Picture: Justin Sanson
Parramatta Eels signing Suaia Matagi has been an avid participant, playing daily in the off-season.
The respected footballer, who was jailed in his younger years and turned his life around with sport, told The Standard the initiative was beneficial for the region.
But Matagi, who would stop by the fields with his eight-year-old son, said taking the opportunity away from “the next generation” could prove problematic.
“It’s sad ... what are these kids going to do now?” he said.
media_camera Blake Austin playing with MCW tag in November. Picture: Justin Sanson media_camera Eel Suaia Matagi with his son Christopher, at the fields last year. Picture: Justin Sanson
“At least 90 per cent of them will say they haven’t got a positive role model ... and a lot of people are incarcerated (when they don’t have) a positive role model.
“Here, they get into tag and meet awesome blokes like Oz (Tupai) ... and it’s good for the young guys to mix and mingle.
“The bigger picture is it’s keeping them healthy and happy, and they have something positive to look forward to.”
Mr Tupai and Matagi said they had seen attitude shifts in the youngsters.
Parents have also praised the men for getting their children “off the couch and out of the house”.
media_camera Ken Aumua, Osselan Tupai and Ejay Taulii want to be able to play oztag for free at the council park. Picture: Justin Sanson
“You shouldn’t have to pay to do something positive, especially when it can help out and contribute to bringing the community closer,” Matagi said.
A council spokesman said: “The area that is being used by oztag at Popendetta Park is currently booked to an approved user, Mt Druitt Town Rangers Football Club. Council’s policy is to give priority to those groups that have booked and paid fees.”
The spokesman said the council wanted to work with the group.
“We have a solid record of working with sporting groups to make sure their needs are met,” the spokesman said.
Mr Tupai said: “It sucks it had to get to this ... all I care about is the boys being able to play in the park.”
